In the field of renewable fine chemicals, the selective hydrogenation of biomass-derived benzoic acid (BA) into cyclohexane carboxylic acid (CCA) holds a pivotal position. Herein, a series of nitrogen (N) and sulfur (S) co-doped Ru-based porous carbon catalysts were synthesized using a combination of soft template and impregnation methods and tested for the hydrogenation of BA. The best performance was obtained on a Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst, giving a cyclohexane carboxylic acid yield of 99.5 % and a turnover frequency of 609.4 h −1 at 90 °C and 1 MPa. Such good reactivity is related to the synergy of S, N co-doping, which enhances the Ru dispersion and optimizes the electronic structure of Ru nanoparticles for BA adsorption. Furthermore, the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst exhibits good cycling stability. The porous structure, charge transfer, N, S co-doping synergistic effect, catalyst active sites, and catalytic reaction kinetics model were in-depth investigated by experimental and theoretical calculations, therefore, the findings in this work provides an efficient catalyst choice for the catalytic hydrogenation of BA under mild conditions. Graphical abstract The prepared Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 showed excellent catalytic activity and selectivity in the hydrogenation of benzoic acid to cyclohexane carboxylic acid, and it has high stability with cycle at least five times. Image, graphical abstract Keywords N, S co-doping Selective hydrogenation synergistic effect Ru nanoparticles Porous structure Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Catalytic hydrogenation is very important in many fields, especially in the petroleum industry, fine chemical, renewable energy, and environmental protection, which has great potential to improve energy efficiency, reduce pollution and promote sustainable development [1–5]. Selective hydrogenation of benzoic acid (BA) to cyclohexane carboxylic acid (CCA) is a typical example [6–8]. In addition, CCA, as a raw material for organic synthesis, plays a vital role in essential organic intermediate for key drugs, such as ansatrienin, caprolactam, and praziquantel [9–11]. However, it requires harsh condition to hydrogenate aromatic ring of BA because it has to overcome the high resonance energy of the benzene ring [12–14]. Traditionally, the selective hydrogenation of BA was achieved by using Na-K alloys [15]. However, the recovery of reducing agent is challenging and can lead to the wastage of raw materials. Hence, the replacement of traditional catalysts with reusable and efficient heterogeneous catalysts for selective hydrogenation of BA has attracted widespread attention. Recently, various supported metal catalysts (such as Pd, Ru, Rh, and Ni) have been applied for the BA hydrogenation [16–23]. For example, it was reported that supported Pd/carbon catalyst can catalyze molten BA to CCA without any solvent [12]. Unfortunately, the reaction was typically conducted under harsh conditions, including high temperatures (150–200 °C) and high H2 pressures (10–15 MPa) or in sc-CO2 [24,25]. Xia et al. reported that BA hydrogenation was carried out on Ru nanoparticles (NPs) supported on high-specific-surface area mesoporous C-TiO2 and a CCA selectivity of 100 % at a BA conversion of 99 % was obtained at 2.5 MPa H2 and 100 °C for 2 h [26]. Zhang et al. prepared Ni2Mg0.5Al-MMO catalysts by a hydrothermal calcination reduction method, on which a BA conversion of 99 % and a CCA selectivity of 98 % were obtained within 3 h under 150 °C and 5.0 MPa H2 [27]. Despite all the progresses, high conversions can only be achieved at relatively high hydrogen pressure (>2.5 MPa), high temperatures (>100 °C), or long reaction time. Such harsh reaction conditions not only result in energy and hydrogen inefficiency, but also restrict their commercial scale application. Therefore, highly efficient heterogeneous catalysts operated under mild conditions are the key to solve these problems. Carbon materials (e.g., porous carbon materials) have been widely used as excellent supports owing to their adjustable surface properties, large surface area, high structural stability and excellent conductivity [28–31]. These properties can promote catalytic activity in hydrogenation. However, the weak interaction between metals and pristine carbon material supports may result in metal aggregation or loss of active metal during the reaction, thereby limiting their application [32,33]. Various methods have been applied to manipulate the support properties, such as refining, graphitization, surface modification, and coating [34–38]. The modification of carbon structures through the addition of heteroatoms (such as N, O, S, P, etc.) to improve physical and chemical properties is an attractive way [39–43]. For example, heteroatoms play a crucial role in controlling the size of metal NPs, and influencing the microenvironment of the metal active sites [44,45]. Tang et al. presented RuPd alloy NPs supported on N‑doped carbon as an efficient and stable catalyst (RuPd/CN) on account of the double metals regulation along with the N atoms boosting the catalytic activity, on which a BA conversion of 67 % and a CCA selectivity of 100 % were obtained at 85 °C and 0.1 MPa H2 atmosphere within 6 h [10]. Additionally, Cao et al. reported that the formation of a Ru-S interface through S doping resulted in a high conversion (97.8 %) of BA within 4 h The S doping increases the active sites of the catalyst, which is beneficial for the adsorption and activation of BA [46]. More importantly, co-doping of N and S can generate synergistic effects and improve the chemical and physical properties of the carbon supports [47,48]. Luque et al. reported an Au-Pd NPs supported on N, S-doped ordered mesoporous carbon (Au-Pd/IBOMC) for the hydrogenation of phenol, and the catalyst displayed excellent performance with a conversion of 98.0 % and selectivity of 96.0 % under mild reaction conditions [47]. Bai et al. prepared a N, S-doped carbon-supported Co catalysts (5 %Co/NSPC-800) by an impregnation method for the hydrogenation of halonitrobenzene, which showed superior catalytic performance with > 99.9 % selectivity to p-chloroaniline and a turnover frequency (TOF) of 203 h −1 [49]. Therefore, the co-doping strategy is a promising approach to enhance the catalytic performance of hydrogenation reaction. Herein, we prepared N, S-doped porous carbons (NSC) based on a soft template method and supported Ru catalyst by an impregnation method. The catalysts showed good performance in the hydrogenation of BA, with the best results obtained on a Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst (a BA conversion of 99.5 %, a CCA selectivity of 100 % and a turnover frequency of 609.4 h −1 at 90 °C). Furthermore, various characterizations along with density functional theory (DFT) calculation revealed that S, N co-doping has a synergistic effect in promoting the dispersion of Ru species and enhancing the adsorption of BA by manipulation of electronic feature of the Ru species via their interaction with the support, which thereby improved the catalytic performance. 2 Results and discussion The route for the preparation of NSC based on soft-templating synthesis was illustrated in Fig. 1 . First, F127, 3-Amino-5-mercapto-1,2,4-triazole (AMTA), resorcinol (RC), thiourea (CH4N2S), and hexamethylenetetramine (HMT) with certain amounts were dissolved in deionized water under stirring. Then high-temperature hydrothermal self-assembly was carried out to synthesize a precursor of spherical porous carbon material rich in S and N elements. Subsequently, the template agent F127 was removed by high temperature pyrolysis to obtain NSC carbon material. Finally, the supported catalyst was obtained by loading Ru nanoparticles via an impregnation method. It is worth mentioning that AMTA mainly provides nitrogen and sulfur sources, in which active hydrogen forms hydrogen bonds with the template agent F127, the hydrolysis of HMT releases formaldehyde and forms a cross-linked structure with RC, allowing AMTA to be embedded in the cross-linked structure, thereby affecting the morphology of porous carbon. The SEM images of the catalysts in Fig. 2 and Fig. S1 reveal the different morphologies of the catalysts depending on the dopant quantities. The Ru/PFC-800 catalyst is in form of irregular blocks. When N and S are doped, the catalyst becomes spherical. Further observation reveals that the S-doping amount can change the size and surface roughness of the spheres. This may be due to the synergistic effect of S-containing functions with N-containing functional groups to regulate particle size and the S-doping increases the degree of graphitization of the support to reduce the surface roughness of the spheres. However, over-doping of S in the support (i.e., the Ru/N1.5S2.0C-800) results in a rougher surface (Fig. 2e and j) compared with the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 (Fig. 2d and i), due to structural distortions and partial collapse of the carbon skeleton via heavily S-doping [50]. The TEM images of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 3a -c and Fig. S2–3. It is clear that the N and S co-doped catalysts contain smaller sized Ru NPs (with average diameters of 3.5 - 4.1 nm) compared to the Ru/PFC-800 (with an average sized of 6.3 nm). These results indicate that N and S co-doping can effectively promote the dispersion of the Ru species. The HRTEM image of the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 (Fig. 3d) shows a lattice spacing of 0.218 nm, which is consistent with lattice distance of Ru (101) plane [51]. Fig. 3e shows the high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) image of the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800. The even distribution of Ru, S, N and C can be revealed by EDS elemental mapping (Fig. 3f). Ru metal content is mainly analyzed by ICP, the Ru load of all catalysts is lower than the actual load (Table S1). This may be due to the loss of Ru metal during the washing process. Therefore, the content of Ru in each catalyst washing solution was tested (Table S1), and the results were consistent with speculation. The surface features of the catalysts were characterized by FT-IR spectroscopy (Fig. 4 a and Fig. S4a). Each sample has a large and broad band at around 3450 cm−1, corresponding to the stretching vibration of OH and NH bonds [52]. The band at 1620 cm−1 is assigned to stretching vibration of C = C bond, which indicates that the resorcinol in the raw material still retains C = C bond under high temperature calcination [53]. Interestingly, a peak of CN stretching vibration was observed at 1200 cm−1 after nitrogen doping in all catalysts except for the Ru/PFC [54]. This result indicates that AMTA was successfully embedded into the cross-linked structure and decomposed into CN during high-temperature heating process. The XRD patterns of the catalysts (Fig. 4b and Fig. S4b) exhibited a wide diffraction centered at 2θ of 25°, which is assigned to (002) plane of graphitic carbon. It is worth noting that all catalysts show typical diffraction of Ru (101) facet at 2θ of 42°, but its intensity is too weak, making it difficult to calculate the particle size of Ru metal. To further investigate the impact of S and N doping on carbon structures, the Raman spectra are shown in Fig. 4c and Fig. S4c. The D-band (representing the vibrations of sp³-hybridized carbon atoms in defects or disordered carbon) and the G-band (representing the vibrations of sp²-hybridized carbon atoms in graphitic hexagonal lattices) were detected at 1350 and 1580 cm⁻¹ in all samples, respectively [55]. The relative intensities of the D-band (D) and G-band (G) provide crucial evidence for studying the characteristics of carbon materials. The D/G ratios of the N-doped, N and S co-doped catalysts (0.96 – 1.10) are lower than that of Ru/PFC-800 (1.22), indicating that S and N doping enhanced the degree of graphitization [56,57]. Moreover, the D/G ratio of the Ru/N1.5C-800 (1.07) is higher than that of the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 (0.96), indicating that appropriate S and N co-doping can increase the degree of graphitization [58]. The pore structures of the catalyst were evaluated by N2 adsorption/desorption analysis. As illustrated in Fig. S5a, all the prepared samples exhibited typical type-I isotherm, clearly indicating the presence of numerous mesopores structures [59]. The pore size distributions of the catalysts (Fig. S5a-c) confirm the main mesoporous structure of the catalyst. The specific surface areas of catalysts are 50, 39, and 15 m2 g −1 for the Ru/S 1.5N1.5C-800, Ru/N1.5C-800 and Ru/PFC-800, respectively (Table S2), indicating that N, S co-doping could significantly enhance the catalyst surface area. This is mainly due to the role of N and S functional groups as shape-directing agents in the catalyst pores and the carbon lattice interlayer spacing is increased by N, S co-doping [60,61]. Notably, the specific surface area of the Ru/ N1.5S1.5C-900 (46 m2 g −1) is lower than those of the Ru/ N1.5S1.5C-700 (81 m2 g −1) and Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 (50 m2 g −1), indicating that high-temperature carbonization may further cause crumble of the carbon structure, resulting in a decreased in its surface area. However, the surface area of the Ru/N1.5S2.0C-800 is only 10 m2 g −1, indicating that over-doping of in S sources can lead to further structural distortions, potentially causing partial collapse of the carbon skeleton [50]. Evidently, doping with appropriate N/S ratio enables the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 having a relatively high surface area and pore volume facilitate the diffusion of reactants and the high exposure of Ru metal active sites [62]. The oxidation states and surface atomic compositions of the catalysts were analyzed by XPS. Fig. S6 reveals that the Ru/N1.5SxC catalysts are primarily comprised of Ru, N, S, and C and their contents are summarized in table S3, which are consistent with the TEM mapping results. The peaks of Ru0 3p1/2 and Ru0 3p3/2 for the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 are assigned to approximately 484.2 eV and 461.7 eV, respectively (Fig. 4d and Fig. S4d) [63]. Compared to Ru/N1.5C-800 and Ru/PFC, the binding energies (BEs) of the Ru 3p of the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 shift to lower values by 0.6 – 0.9 eV, indicating that the electron transfer from N, S co-doping carbon support to Ru, and the Ru nanoparticles of Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 have more electron rich feature than the Ru/N1.5C-800 and Ru/PFC. Other N, S co-doping catalysts exhibit the same phenomenon as Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800, but with less negative shift compared to Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800. Fig. 5a displays the N 1 s XPS spectrum of the Ru/N1.5S1.5–800, revealing four distinct peaks upon deconvolution. These peaks correspond to pyridinic nitrogen (397.5 eV), pyrrolic nitrogen (399.8 eV), and graphitic nitrogen (401.3 eV) [64,65]. It is noteworthy that compared to the Ru/N1.5C-800, the BEs of N in the Ru/N1.5S1.0C-800, Ru/N1.5S1.5C-700, Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800, Ru/N1.5S1.5C-900, and Ru/N1.5S2.0C-800 systematically shift to higher values, and this trend is exactly opposite to that on the Ru species. Furthermore, the S 2p XPS peaks centered at 163.6 eV and 164.8 eV match with C–S–C S 2p3/2 and C–S–C S 2p1/2, respectively. Another peak at 164.0 eV corresponds to the Ru–S bond, proving the coordination between Ru with S and the possible to regulate the interaction between Ru nanoparticles and the support (Fig. 5b) [66]. The other two peaks with BEs of 167.4 eV and 168.3 eV are assigned to C–SOx–C and C–SO2–C, respectively, which could be due to oxidation from exposure to air [67]. These results reveal that heteroatom doping can affect the electronic structure of Ru and its interaction with the support. And the introduction of S atoms provides a new pathway for electron transfer and creates a synergistic effect with N atoms. This synergistic effect effectively enhances the charge transfer between N, S heteroatoms and Ru nanoparticles, strengthening the coordination interaction between these species, thereby improving the dispersibility of Ru nanoparticles and the catalyst durability [68,69]. The thermal stability of the catalysts was investigated using thermogravimetric analysis (TG). As depicted in Fig. S7a-b, all catalysts exhibited notable weight loss peaks in the range of 30–65 °C, likely attributed to the desorption of water molecules adsorbed on the catalyst surfaces [70]. As the temperature raised to 900 °C, the weight loss of each catalyst remains minimal, indicating their remarkable thermal stability. Further H2-TPD was conducted to understand of hydrogen adsorption behaviors of the catalysts (Fig. S7c). It can be observed that there are two peaks at approximately 75 and 160 °C in all catalysts, which is attributed to weak adsorption of hydrogen species. The corresponding strong adsorption peak of hydrogen species can be observed at approximately 415 °C over the catalysts. Compared with the Ru/PFC-800, the desorption peaks of chemically adsorbed hydrogen on other catalysts show a slight shift towards lower temperatures, indicating that S and N doping are beneficial for reducing strong hydrogen adsorption and preventing hydrogen poisoning [71]. The dispersion of Ru was calculated in Table S1, it can be found that the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 has the highest Ru dispersion, indicating that more Ru active sites are exposed on the catalyst surface. 2.1 Catalytic performance The catalytic testing results are summarized in Table 1 . It is worth noting that the hydrogenation of BA easily forms benzyl alcohol on metal catalysts [72], but as shown in Table 1, the desired CCA is the only product on all the catalysts. Such high selectivity (100 %) is mainly attributed to the fact that the benzene ring could more easily reacted on Ru-based catalysts than the carboxyl group, as the hydrogen on the carboxyl group of BA attacks the benzene ring to promote its hydrogenation [11,73]. Clearly, the Ru/PFC-800 catalyst exhibits lower BA conversion (70.9 %) and CCA yield (70.9 %) compared to the Ru/N1.5C-800 (77.8 % conversion of BA and 77.8 % yield of CCA), which is attributed to increased Ru dispersion by N doping. Additionally, the co-doped Ru/N1.5SxC catalysts exhibit better catalytic performance than Ru/N1.5C-800. The BET (Table S2) result demonstrates that the low surface area of Ru/N1.5S2.0C-800 catalyst, which leads to fewer exposed active sites, may be the main reason for its lower activity. These results prove that the synergistic effect of N, S co-doping can alter the properties of the catalyst, which is beneficial for improving its activity. Particularly, the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst exhibits the highest catalytic activity with a BA conversion of 99.5 %, a CCA yield of 99.5 % and the specific activity of 10.0 mmol g −1 (Table 1), which is mainly attributed to its highest Ru dispersion (Fig. 3). The efficiency of the catalytic system be further evaluated at ratios S/C = 12.2/1 in Table S4. It can be found that the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst also has the highest catalytic activity (95.5 %), selectivity (100 %) and specific activity (93.5 mmol g −1) at 90 °C and 1 MPa for 10 h, and the activity laws of all catalysts are consistent with the ratio S/C = 1.2/1. These results imply that the appropriate N/S ratio doping can further enhance the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Moreover, TOFs of the catalysts were calculated to compare their intrinsic activities. The Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 gives the highest TOF of 609.4 h −1 calculated by H2-TPD, which is 2-fold higher than that of the Ru/N1.5C-800 (263.3 h −1) and 3-fold higher than that of the Ru/PFC-800 (164.4 h −1). The impressive activity of Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 is higher than the other catalytic hydrogenation catalysts of BA in literature (Table S5). This result indicates that appropriate N, S co-doping synergistic effect can further promote the activity of each Ru active site. The reaction was also conducted on the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst in the presence of different solvents. As summarized in Table S6, both protic and apolar organic solvents are not conducive to the reaction, high BA conversions were obtained in polar solvents such as water (95.2 %) and ethanol (86.3 %) due to their strong H-bond donor capability [74,75]. The catalytic performance of the catalysts was evaluated at different reaction times. The reaction time versus BA conversion plots at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 6a -c and Fig. S8a-c. It is clear that the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst exhibits superior activities than other catalysts, with a complete conversion of BA at 90 °C under 1 MPa H2 within 2 h The reaction kinetics of the catalysts under different temperatures and durations were studied based on reaction rates, as shown in Fig. 6d-f and Fig. S8d-f. It can be seen that the kinetics curves conform to the first order reaction. The Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst has a higher reaction rate constant (k = 0.078 min−1) compared to other catalysts, possibly due to its more active sites and different Ru electronic structures. Moreover, the reaction rate increases with increasing temperature, and the reaction rate of Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst is most affected by temperature changes (Fig. S9). As shown in Fig. S10a-b, the impact of reaction temperature on catalytic activity is also investigated. As the temperature increases from 50 to 90 °C, the BA conversion of the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 increased from 50.6 to 99.5 %. Notably, during the hydrogenation of BA to produce CCA, the CCA formation rate of the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst remain at the forefront. Additionally, we have conducted thorough investigations into the catalytic reactions under varying H2 pressure conditions (Fig. S10c-d). The results indicate that with the increase of pressure, the catalytic hydrogenation activity of Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst for BA also increases. Based on DFT calculations, the adsorption energy of BA and CCA on Ru/PFC, Ru/NC and Ru/NSC are measured (Fig. 7 ). It can be seen that Ru/NSC (−2.43 eV) exhibits higher adsorption energy of BA than that of the Ru/PFC (−1.40 eV) and Ru/NC (−1.99 eV) as the adsorption mode. The adsorption energy of 2.43 eV means a moderate or strong adsorption, which is beneficial for the adsorption and activation of reactants. Therefore, it indicates that the activation of BA on the Ru/NSC is easier than that on the Ru/PFC and Ru/NC, and leading to a higher conversion of BA over Ru/NSC. These results demonstrate that N, S co-doping can increase the adsorption capacity of BA and promote catalytic hydrogenation performance. Interestingly, the adsorption energy of the Ru/PFC (−0.75 eV), Ru/NC (−0.66 eV) and Ru/NSC (−0.69 eV) for CCA is relatively weak, indicating the hydrogenated CCA can desorption in time, and the corresponding active site can be empty, which is beneficial for the continuous progress of the hydrogenation reaction and the improvement of the selectivity of CCA, and the results are consistent with the experiment. Bader charge analysis further demonstrates the electron transfer between the support and Ru nanoparticles is shown in Fig. S11 and table S7. It can be observed that Ru nanoparticles in Ru/NSC exhibit a lower positive charge (+0.73 e) than those in Ru/NC (+0.89 e) and Ru/PFC (+1.08 e), indicating the Ru nanoparticles in Ru/NSC exhibit minimal electron transfer to the support compared to other systems, resulting in the Ru nanoparticles possessing a higher electronegativity. This facilitates electron donation from the Ru nanoparticles to BA, effectively enhancing their adsorption energy. In addition, it can be found that the S atoms donate electrons and the N atom accepts electrons according to the Bader charge results. Compared to Ru/NC, the N atom in Ru/NSC accepts fewer electrons, suggesting S-doping can effectively reduce the ability of N atom to accept electrons. These results may be indicate that the synergistic effect between electron donating ability of S and electron accepting ability of N, leading to electron transfer between Ru nanoparticles S atoms and N atom, thereby enables the Ru nanoparticles coordination with N, S heteroatoms and anchor on the support [76], which is consistent with the results of XPS. Additionally, the adsorption energy of BA increases with the Bader charge of Ru decrease, indicating that Ru/NSC has better catalytic hydrogenation activity for BA over that of Ru/NC and Ru/NC. Furthermore, to evaluate the general applicability of the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst, various benzoic acid derivatives were selected as reaction substrates for experimentation (details can be found in Table 2 ). The hydrogenation of o-methylbenzoic acid and 2,4-dimethylbenzoic acid (entries 2 and 3) has very lower conversions (40.3 and 41.6 %) compared to benzoic acid. Because methyl has the ability to donate electrons, it produces a localization effect, resulting in a lower electron cloud density on the carbon connected to it, thereby slowing down the hydrogenation rate. The hydrogenation of Methyl benzoate reaches 100 % conversion (entries 4). However, for terephthalic acid and 2-aminoterephthalic acid (entries 5 and 6), high conversion (99.9 and 82.4 %) can only be achieved under harsh conditions. Due to the presence of two carboxyl groups, its solubility in water greatly decreases, which is not conducive to mass transfer between the catalyst and the substrate. This fully demonstrates the excellent catalytic capability of Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 in the selective hydrogenation reaction of benzoic acid derivatives, further validating its broad applicability and catalytic efficiency. To investigate the stability of Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst in the hydrogenation of BA, twelve cycles were carried out under optimized reaction conditions (Fig. 8 ). The Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst showed good stability with maintained high activity and CCA selectivity during the testing process. Based on the corresponding XRD patterns (Fig. S12) and TEM images (Fig. S13), it can be observed that the crystalline state and dispersion of Ru have basically remained unchanged after five runs. 3 Conclusions In summary, the soft templating combined with solution impregnation method was adopted to synthesis of the Ru-based porous carbon N and S co-doped catalyst, which can be used for the hydrogenation of BA to CCA. Herein, The Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst exhibits remarkable higher conversion (99.5 %), reaction rates (k = 0.078 min−1), and TOF (609.4 h −1) compared to other catalysts for the catalytic hydrogenation of BA at 90 °C 1 MPa. Experimental and theoretical calculations results show that the excellent catalytic performance of the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst is mainly attributed to the synergistic effect of N, S co-doping in the carbon framework, which changes the porous structure of the carbon support and the electronic structure of the support and Ru nanoparticles, thereby increasing the specific surface area of the support, the Ru dispersion, and the desorption ability of hydrogen and adsorption ability of substrate. Remarkably, the optimized Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 demonstrated exceptional stability, maintaining its high catalytic activity even after undergoing twelve cycles of reaction. This finding underscores the potential of this catalyst for long-term applications in various catalytic processes. Its outstanding performance under varying temperature and pressure conditions further underscores its broad application prospects in the field of catalysis. coredata.dc:description: In the field of renewable fine chemicals, the selective hydrogenation of biomass-derived benzoic acid (BA) into cyclohexane carboxylic acid (CCA) holds a pivotal position. Herein, a series of nitrogen (N) and sulfur (S) co-doped Ru-based porous carbon catalysts were synthesized using a combination of soft template and impregnation methods and tested for the hydrogenation of BA. The best performance was obtained on a Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst, giving a cyclohexane carboxylic acid yield of 99.5 % and a turnover frequency of 609.4 h −1 at 90 °C and 1 MPa. Such good reactivity is related to the synergy of S, N co-doping, which enhances the Ru dispersion and optimizes the electronic structure of Ru nanoparticles for BA adsorption. Furthermore, the Ru/N1.5S1.5C-800 catalyst exhibits good cycling stability. The porous structure, charge transfer, N, S co-doping synergistic effect, catalyst active sites, and catalytic reaction kinetics model were in-depth investigated by experimental and theoretical calculations, therefore, the findings in this work provides an efficient catalyst choice for the catalytic hydrogenation of BA under mild conditions.
